Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Bio-Inorganic Chemistry of the Rare Earth Metals: Chemistry Relevant to the Cerium-Dependent Methanol Dehydrogenase
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award through the Chemistry of Life Processes Program and Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Dr. Eric Schelter of the University of Pennsylvania to study the electronic structure of functional model complexes of the active site of the first rare earth-containing metalloenzyme and to synthesize new efficient catalysts for the dehydrogenation of alcohols. It has been recently discovered that M. fumariolicum SoIV, an organism found in the Sofatara Crater in Italy, requires rare earth metals in order to grow. This surprising finding marks the first time that any rare earth elements have been found to be necessary for life. It has also been recently determined that the organism possesses a cerium atom in a key enzyme used to convert methane into a food source for the organism. This project is focused on determining exactly how the cerium center does this and what the role of the rare earth elements are in keeping these microbes alive. This work will have a broad impact on our understanding of the basic features of life and what is required for life to be sustained, even in extremely harsh environments. Graduate students trained through this project will acquire unique and diverse skills at the interface of bioinorganic chemistry and chemical catalysis. The findings of the project will be communicated through outreach programs targeted toward high school students and the general public. Underrepresented groups including women graduate students, an African American graduate student, a visiting African woman scientist and a Latino postdoctoral associate will benefit from support of the project.

Recent studies have shown that the methylotrophic M. fumariolicum SolV has an essential growth requirement for the rare earth metals La-Gd. The methanol dehydrogenase enzyme of M. fumariolicum SolV was determined to have a cerium cation in its active site. This surprising finding marked the first instance that rare earth elements (RE = La-Gd, Sc and Lu) were shown to have an essential biochemical role. The central hypothesis of this application is that the metal redox activity of Ce can be used to evaluate the electronic structure of the active site, that Ce-quinone complexes will similarly induce methanol dehydrogenation in model complexes, and that the strong Lewis acidity of RE cations enable fast and unique reactivity for the cerium methanol dehydrogenase. The team will test the hypothesis through a combination of model complex synthesis, electrochemistry and density functional theory studies. The overall goals of the research are to determine the electronic structure of the cerium active site and to synthesize functional model complexes of the enzyme that catalyze the dehydrogenation of alcohols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this project the research group of Eric J. Schelter at the University of Pennsylvania developed new aerobic oxidation chemistry reminiscent of that performed in the active site of the methanol dehydrogenase enzyme in the extremophilic bacterium Methylacidiphilum fumariolicum SolV. The intellectual merit of this project was the generation of knowledge related to the unique metalloenzyme, in particular its capabilities for the dehydrogenation reaction of alcohols. Using computational chemistry, we analyzed the active site of the enzyme because it contains a cerium metal cation. Our results indicated the cerium cation sets the properties of the active site to improve its efficiency compared to a calcium counterpart. This result was important because it expands our understanding of how different metals leveraged in biochemical pathways contribute to competitive advantage among bacteria. We also used computation chemistry to broadly understand how the combination of cerium ions with different organic groups changed the reactivity of the metal cations. This study added value because it created the capability of predicting the reactivities of different combinations of organic groups with cerium cations, such that combinations can be ‘screened’ using computations before making compounds in the lab. We also achieved new, efficient syntheses of organic compounds called quinoline quinones and studied their properties using electrochemistry and computational chemistry. These results expand our knowledge of the pieces and function of the lanthanide metalloenzyme by drawing analogy to the natural cofactor, pyrroloquinoline quinone (PQQ), present in the active site. We also applied the quinoline quinones in dehydrogenation chemistry of amines, in analogy to the alcohols that are dehydrogenated by the enzyme. Overall this knowledge contributes to our understanding of how elements are essential for different forms of life, and how different metals can express unique biochemistries.

Through the work described in this report we also accomplished broader impact. The two graduate students and one postdoc trained on this project were trained in synthetic and computational chemistry and in using electrochemistry and spectroscopy. These personnel have skills that will support chemical industries, education and national security, for example in the rare earths mining industry. One of the students is pursuing a postdoctoral appointment in synthetic biomimetic chemistry with a goal of entering a career in academics and the second student is now teaching at the college level. Results from this project were disseminated through publications in the chemistry literature. Outreach seminars including (2) science cafes at local bars and (4) talks to high school students (~30 students each) also included content and ideas from this project.
